awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary Diversification and Community Assembly in Melanesian Forest Frogs: Testing the Hypothesis of Replicated Adaptive Radiation
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the mechanisms that generate and regulate biodiversity patterns can provide broad insights into how biological communities assemble and diversify over different timescales. The importance of evolutionary processes for the generation of biodiversity in isolated island systems is well documented. However, the question remains: can processes like speciation and adaptation lead to predictable outcomes during the assembly of biological communities on islands? This study aims to address this question by examining patterns of frog diversity in the Melanesian island archipelagos of the Southwest Pacific. Melanesian forest frogs provide an ideal system to study adaptive processes of diversification because they are distributed across multiple island chains and exhibit a similar set of habitat specialists (ecomorphs), which are unique to each island group. This study will test the hypothesis that these ecologically similar frog communities evolved independently in each archipelago, resulting in the convergence of entire species communities. This project will document a remarkable case of convergent evolution that could provide additional evidence bearing on the evolution and assembly of biological communities worldwide. Portions of this research will also include advanced undergraduate mentoring in science, including genomic sequence capture data collection and analysis. Additionally, the results of this project will be integrated into a classroom learning module geared toward teaching evolutionary concepts to Kansas high school students.

A major goal of this study is to resolve the evolutionary relationships among Melanesian Forest Frogs of the genus Cornufer using an exon capture sequencing approach. Phylogenomic data will be integrated with morphometric and ecological data from all species throughout the Melanesian archipelagos to test whether (1) frog ecomorph communities evolved in each archipelago through independent adaptive radiations, (2) ecomorphs evolved only once and subsequently dispersed across archipelagos, or (3) a combination of both. Macroevolutionary models will then be used to evaluate whether frog communities in each archipelago are more or less ecomorphologically convergent that expected by chance, which may suggest that adaptive diversification and community assembly has been nonrandom in Melanesian Forest Frogs. This study will promote the development of another rich, multi-faceted model system of adaptive radiation for a variety of conceptual evolutionary studies on the process of biological diversification and community assembly.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to test whether macroevolutionary dynamics, such as speciation and adaptation, can lead to predictable outcomes of community assembly in different geographic regions. To investigate this question, we studied Melanesian Forest Frogs (genus Cornufer), representing a major terrestrial vertebrate component of the island archipelagos in the Southwest Pacific, to evaluate whether they have undergone replicated adaptive radiations in different island groups. Using a novel exon-capture probe set, we collected genomic data for nearly all species of Melanesian Forest Frogs, resulting in a 12,000-locus dataset and the first resolved phylogeny for this group of frogs. Biogeographic analyses based on the phylogenomic data support geographically circumscribed patterns of diversification, fulfilling a key prediction of our hypothesis of replicated adaptive radiation (i.e., that communities assembled independently within each archipelago through in-situ speciation and not through dispersal from other regions). We then collected a morphometric dataset for all species of Cornufer (15 measured traits for over 700 individuals, with an average of ~7 individuals measured per species), which was coupled with our phylogeny and previously collected ecological data for analyses into Cornufer ecomorphological evolution and community morphospace convergence between archipelagos. Phylogenetic comparative analyses indicate a strong phenotype-ecotype correlation and more similarity in community morphospace occupancy than expected by chance between two of our focal regions, the Bismarck and Solomon archipelagos. These results suggest that evolutionary phenomena can sometimes result in highly predictable patterns of community assembly over broad timescales. Our research findings into this new empirical study system of adaptive radiation have been presented at several international conferences, and have resulted in two published scientific papers, with three others in preparation. Additionally, this work has provided training and educational outreach opportunities through the following outlets: (1) Graduate student training (for Co-PI) in sophisticated techniques for genomic sequence capture data collection, processing, and analysis, (2) Undergraduate training (for undergraduate mentee of Co-PI) in DNA sequencing, phylogenomic analysis, and scientific manuscript writing, and (3) An evolutionary learning module on adaptive radiation that co-PI Travers presented to high school biology classes at Olathe South High School (Olathe, Kansas, USA) as part of the University of Kansas DNA Day outreach program.
